item.title: Inside Obama's Syria Debate
item.description: With the death toll mounting in the Syrian rebellion, the Obama administration has stepped up calls for Assad to give up power.

item.title: Italy Takes New Tack on Political Deadlock
item.description: Italy's president said Mario Monti's government should remain in power while a group of experts hashes out a blueprint of reforms for a future government, an unusual gambit that essentially buys time to resolve the country's deep political divisions.

item.title: Court Upholds Kenyan Vote
item.description: Kenya's Supreme Court declared this month's presidential elections free and fair, lifting a cloud of political uncertainty hanging over East Africa's biggest economy.

item.title: U.S. Starts Shipping Out of Afghanistan
item.description: The U.S. military has begun to ship mountains of equipment out of Afghanistan on a route that goes through violence-hit areas of Pakistan.

item.title: Hope for Talks With Taliban Sends Karzai to Qatar
item.description: Afghan President Hamid Karzai arrived in Qatar on a trip that Afghan officials have billed as an effort to kick-start a faltering peace process with the Taliban.

item.title: U.S. Hands Over Base to Afghans
item.description: U.S. forces handed over a base in a strategic district of Afghanistan. The move satisfies a demand by President Karzai that U.S. forces leave the area after allegations that the Americans' Afghan counterparts committed human-rights abuses there on U.S. orders.

item.title: Body Found in Tibet Landslide
item.description: Rescuers in Tibet found one body after 83 workers were buried in a landslide at a gold mining site. The fate of the other victims is unknown.

item.title: Principal Killed at Pakistan School
item.description: A man armed with a gun and grenades attacked a school in southern Pakistan on Saturday, killing its principal and wounding six children.

item.title: Mandela Is Treated for Pneumonia
item.description: Former South African President Nelson Mandela is being treated for pneumonia but is responding to doctors' efforts while he remains in the hospital for a third day, South Africa's presidency said.

item.title: Japan Seeks Stronger Mongolia Ties
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe traveled to Mongolia, pledging greater cooperation on energy and trade, as Japan seeks closer ties in the region.

item.title: Tensions Bolster Tokyo Military Bid
item.description: North Korea's increasingly bellicose threats are bolstering Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's long-standing calls to build up Japan's military.

item.title: Argentina Makes Offer to Creditors
item.description: Argentina offered a payment plan to creditors battling for money due on bonds it defaulted on a decade ago. The plan would include interest due, but would extend the payment period for 20 or more years.

item.title: Panel Says Tepco Still Short on Safety
item.description: Japan's Tepco said it won't be restarting the one nuclear power plant it has a chance of running soon after an advisory panel said the company must do more to improve safety.

item.title: Italy's President Moves to End Impasse
item.description: Italy's political limbo was prolonged by at least another day, after the country's president took more time to figure out whether there was any way to form a new government and avoid calling new elections.

item.title: French Data Show Economy Still Soft
item.description: France missed its deficit reduction target last year and consumer spending is contracting, underscoring the challenges faced by President François Hollande in repairing the economy.

item.title: U.S. Military Cuts Rattle Portugal
item.description: On a Portuguese island in the middle of the Atlantic where the U.S.'s Lajes Airbase has been a major employer for decades, news of American military cuts is hitting hard.

item.title: Upheaval in Mali Curbs Drug Traffic
item.description: The French military offensive that evicted Islamist militias from the desert outpost of Gao, Mali, has also driven out drug smugglers.

item.title: Study Sees Increasingly Assertive China
item.description: China appears willing to risk strained relations with neighbors over territorial claims, a report by a Japanese think-tank said.

item.title: At Least 23 Killed in Iraq Blasts
item.description: A string of bombings targeting Shiite mosques in Iraq killed at least 23 people and wounded dozens, officials said.

item.title: Ex-Regulator Gets China Provincial Post
item.description: China formally appointed its former top securities regulator, prominent reformer Guo Shuqing, as acting governor of Shandong province.

item.title: In Cyprus, Goods Hit a Bottleneck
item.description: Businesses across Cyprus are counting the costs of the prolonged bank shutdown, and many suppliers are insisting on only cash payments, leading to bottlenecks in the flow goods to the market.

item.title: Cypriots Hope Tourism Will Be Economic Buoy
item.description: Foreign tourists stroll Cyprus's beaches, unscathed by the nation's troubles. But many Cypriots fret that the nation's crisis will not only imperil its ability to draw foreign business, but could also deal a blow to another pillar of the economy: foreign tourism.

item.title: Channeling Mrs. Thatcher in Tokyo, Seoul
item.description: Margaret Thatcher's ideas are enjoying a renaissance in Asia, where the new leaders of Japan and South Korea embrace the Cold War-era British leader as a role model.

item.title: Arise! Arise! The British Are…Acting!
item.description: On big and small screens, the juicy Yank parts are going to people with names like Day-Lewis. How to fight back.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 29
item.description: In today's pictures, a man takes a nap at a playground in Tokyo, rescuers search for survivors in a collapsed building in Tanzania, people pray in the streets of Bangladesh, and more.
